caseTitle: REX V ANYANWU NWANJOKU OF UMUHU
summary: The appellant, Anyanwu Nwanjoku of Umuhu, was convicted of murder for killing Arungwa Nwokoma, the head of their compound, after a fight with another man was interrupted. The deceased used a switch to separate the combatants, after which the appellant retrieved a matchet and fatally attacked him. The West Africa Court of Appeal upheld the conviction, ruling that the provocation was insufficient to reduce the crime to manslaughter under section 318 of the Criminal Code. The court held that the deceased's actions were lawful and reasonable as compound head, and the use of a deadly weapon in response to minimal force did not meet the threshold for mitigation. The appeal was dismissed based on established common law principles requiring proportionality and reasonableness in assessing provocation.
verdict: Conviction for murder upheld; appeal dismissed
citations: Rex v. Simpson, 11 Cr. App. Rep. 218
Reg. v. Welsh, 11 Cox's Criminal Cases 336
R. v. Alexander, 9 Criminal Appeal Reports 139
R. v. Losbini, 11 Criminal Appeal Reports 7
R. v. Bourne (5 C. & P. 120, 172 English Reports, p. 903)
Reg. v. Sherwood (1 C. & K. 556 ; 174 English Reports, 936)
R. v. Lynch (5 C. & P. 324; 172 English Reports 995)
Rex v. George Hayward (6 C. & P. 157; 172 English Reports 1188)
Rex v. William Richard Hall (21 Cr. Appl. Rep. 48)
rationaleHighlights: Provocation must come from the deceased to reduce murder to manslaughter
Degree of provocation judged by its effect on a reasonable person, not subjective reaction
Use of deadly weapon (matchet) disproportionate to minor provocation (switch)
Deceased was justified in stopping unlawful fight as compound head
No evidence of excessive force by deceased
Primary rage stemmed from fight interruption, not personal attack
English common law principles apply to interpretation of Nigerian Criminal Code
Precedent from Rex v. George Hayward controls decision
confidenceNotes: High confidence in factual accuracy based on detailed judicial reasoning and clear citation of legal precedents. Jurisdictional application of English common law principles to Nigerian Criminal Code confirmed by court.
